body: Like many others before him, Yaakov Riegler was known to child welfare officials long before he was beaten unconscious in September, his skull fractured and one leg twisted so viciously that it broke. And once again, the death of a child in New York City is raising familiar questions about caseworkers who appear to have acted at cross purposes,
title: A Child's Death Prompts Questions Of How Efforts Failed to Save Him

body: Unlike many of his predecessors, the new Brooklyn Democratic leader, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., doesn't like to be called "boss." He prefers "coordinator slash mediator." Mr. Norman, the first black and at 39 years old, very likely the youngest leader of the most influential Democratic organization in the state, will need all the mediating
title: In Brooklyn, Party Leader Sees New Era

body: New York City's welfare agency, acting in the case of an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who was a suspected victim of child abuse, took two critical steps in opposite directions in November 1989, an official familiar with the case said yesterday. In response to calls of concern from school officials, a social worker for the city's Human Resources
title: Inconsistent Actions Seen in Case Of Boy Said to Be Victim of Abuse

body: The publisher of The Daily News, James Hoge, yesterday criticized a report in The New York Times about his paper's use of out-of-state security guards, calling it "distorted and unfair." The report, a front-page article in The Times yesterday, quoted two former guards as saying they had been instructed to act as "bait" for strikers in the
title: News Chief Assails 'Bait' Report

body: The Brooklyn woman who is accused of killing her 8-year-old son was removed from probation last March, even though the city's welfare agency was already investigating new child-abuse complaints against her. A spokesman for the city's Department of Probation, Gerry Migliore, said yesterday that the department had not known of the new charges. When
title: Two Agencies In Conflict In Abuse Case

body: The public school attended by an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy whose mother is accused of killing him alerted welfare officials at least three times over the last year because teachers suspected the boy was a victim of child abuse, the school's principal said yesterday. The principal, Philip Tritt, of Public School 205 in the Bensonhurst section, said a
title: School Feared Borough Park Boy Was Victim of Abuse

body: A Brooklyn woman with a history of violence against her children was arrested and charged yesterday with the murder of her 8-year-old son in a case that revealed what one public official called a little-known problem: child abuse in the family-oriented, tightly knit Orthodox Jewish community. The woman, 33-year-old Shulamis Riegler, was taken into
title: Murder Case In Community Of Families

body: At the funeral on Tuesday of Rabbi Meir Kahane, the militant Brooklyn-born rabbi got the honor and acceptance he never got in life. Among the thousands of mourners were the leaders of several establishment Jewish organizations that had once vilified him as a racist, a meglomaniac and "a fringe person." In the day since the funeral, a debate has
title: Outpouring for Kahane: Pity or a New Respect?

body: In a white brick synagogue near his boyhood home in Brooklyn, Rabbi Meir Kahane was eulogized yesterday as a holy man who, like the prophets of old, was often shunned by his people. Thousands of Jews jammed the synagogue and the streets outside. They included Kahane partisans crying for revenge, and leaders of mainstream Jewish organizations who
title: Grief and Anger at Kahane's Funeral

body: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the founder of the Jewish Defense League and leader of a militant anti-Arab fringe movement in Israel, was assassinated last night by a gunman during a Zionist conference at a hotel in midtown Manhattan, the police said. The gunman was then shot and wounded by a police officer from the United States Postal Service as he fled the
title: KAHANE IS KILLED AFTER GIVING TALK IN NEW YORK HOTEL

body: It was just a single handwritten note, scrawled in broken English and found on the ground in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. But its ominous message -- a threat to kill Jewish children in retaliation for recent violence in Jerusalem -- sent tremors through the heavily Jewish neighborhoods of Flatbush and Borough Park. title: Anti-Jewish Note Chills Neighborhood

body: The state court decision on Tuesday barring top New York City officials from holding political party offices set the stage yesterday for a battle over the Brooklyn Democratic leadership. The rivals are a close ally of Mayor David N. Dinkins and a supporter of a Dinkins opponent, former Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, in last year's Democratic
title: Brooklyn Democrats Fight for Top Party Post

body: LEAD: Rosemary Baker hummed to herself on the No. 5 train to the Bronx on her way to work at a construction site. title: Metro Matters; Life Goes On: Shrugging Off Crime and Fear
